questions.text: Which of the following can be seen in the image below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image demonstrates both festooned pupil and keratic precipitates.

Festooned pupil

  • Usually seen following the application of mydriatics in chronic anterior uveitis. This occurs because of the presence of segmental posterior synechiaebetween the pupillary margin and lens capsule.
  • In severe cases of plastic iritis or after recurrent attacks of iritis, the whole pupillary margin becomes adherent to the lens capsule. This is known as ring synechiae or seclusio pupillae. If unrelieved, it inevitably leads to a secondary angle closure glaucoma.

Keratic precipitates are proteinaceous cellular deposits on the corneal endothelium. Seen in anterior uveitis.

Hypopyon (Option D) is the collection of pus at the bottom of the anterior chamber. Seen in infected wounds and ulcers of the cornea, and occasionally in iridocyclitis. Not seen in the image.

Hypopyon

choices.text: Consists of pars plana and pars plicata
Contraction of the ciliary body helps in accommodation

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the ciliary body?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ciliary body is an anteroposteriorly oriented, isosceles-triangle–shaped structure whose base faces anteriorly; its bulk is formed by unstriped (smooth) ciliary muscle fibres arranged in longitudinal, radial, and circular bundles.

The ciliary body has three basic functions:

  1. Aqueous humour dynamics: Nonpigmented epithelium in the pars plicata actively secretes and regulates the outflow of aqueous, maintaining intraocular pressure. (Option C)
  2. Accommodation: Contraction of the ciliary muscle relaxes zonular fibres, allowing the lens to increase curvature for near vision. (Option B)
  3. Vitreous support: Pars plana epithelium synthesises hyaluronate, essential for the gelatinous consistency of the vitreous.

The inner surface of the ciliary body is divided into two regions: (Option A)

  • The anteriorpart (pars plicata) is corrugated with a number of folds running in an anteroposterior direction. It is the primary site of aqueous humour secretion.
  • The posterior part (pars plana) is smooth. It contributes mucopolysaccharide (hyaluronate) to the vitreous body.

Vascular supply: Dual arterial inflow from the long posterior ciliary arteries and anterior ciliary arteries provides high-flow perfusion to support its secretory, contractile, and nutritive functions.

choices.text: The nucleus of the crystalline lens

questions.text: The ophthalmic artery provides blood supply to which of the following structures of the eye?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rod and cone photoreceptors are supplied by branches of the ophthalmic artery.

The inner retinal circulation (central retinal artery) and choroidal circulation (short posterior ciliary arteries) derive directly from the ophthalmic artery to nourish neural and photoreceptor layers.

The cornea and the crystalline lens are avascular structures of the eye. They receive nutrients by diffusion from the tear film, aqueous humour, and vitreous, not by direct arterial perfusion. (Option A and C)

questions.text: Anterior uveitis can occur in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sarcoidosis, juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), and tuberculosis are known causes of anterior uveitis, appearing in both granulomatous and non-granulomatous chronic categories.

Anterior uveitis is classified by granulomatous versus non-granulomatous and by acute versus chronic onset, encompassing a broad spectrum of systemic and infectious diseases.

Recognition of these categories directs targeted systemic workup and management (e.g., ACE levels for sarcoid, HLA-B27 for JIA, Mantoux/IGRA for TB).

Diseases Associated with Uveitis

1) Non-granulomatous Uveitis

Acute

  • Idiopathic
  • Infectious: Mumps, Influenza, Adenovirus, Measles, Chlamydia, Lyme disease, Leptospirosis, Kawasaki disease, Rickettsial diseases.
  • HLA-B27-associated: Ankylosing spondylitis, Reiter syndrome, Isolated HLA-B27 positivity (no systemic disease).
  • Behçet disease
  • Psoriatic arthritis
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Lens-induced uveitis: Phacolytic, Phacoanaphylactic, Phacotoxic
  • UGH syndrome (uveitis-glaucoma-hyphaema)
  • Corneal graft rejection
  • Glaucomatocyclitic crisis (Posner-Schlossman syndrome)
  • Trauma
  • Anterior segment ischaemia
  • Secondary syphilis

Chronic

  • Juvenile chronic arthritis
  • Chronic iridocyclitis of children
  • Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis

2) Granulomatous Uveitis

Acute

  • Rare

Chronic

  • Sarcoidosis
  • Herpes simplex
  • Vogt - Koyanagi - Harada disease
  • Herpes zoster
  • Varicella
  • Syphilis
  • Tuberculosis
  • Leprosy
  • Brucellosis
  • Phacoanaphylactic uveitis

questions.text: Granulomatous uveitis is seen in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome is a rare autoimmune, multisystem disorder marked by bilateral granulomatous panuveitis along with neurological (meningismus, CSF pleocytosis), auditory (sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus), and dermatological (vitiligo, poliosis, alopecia) features.

  • There is a chronic granulomatous iridocyclitis, with an exudative choroiditis, which often leads to an exudative detachment of the retina.
  • The ocular inflammation is accompanied by a patchy depigmentation of the skin and whitening of the hair, eyebrows and eyelashes (poliosis).
  • The cause is unknown but may be an autoimmune response against melanocytes.

Treatment:

  • Inflammation is controlled with high doses of systemic steroids, and once improvement occurs, gradually tapered over months to years.
  • Immunosuppressive drugs- if steroid intolerant/resistant

Other causes of chronic granulomatous uveitis include:

  • Tuberculosis
  • Syphilis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Leprosy
  • Herpes simplex, Herpes zoster
  • Brucellosis
  • Phacoanaphylactic

Explanation of Other Options:

Fuchs disease (Option B): Chronic non-granulomatous iridocyclitis with stellate keratic precipitates and absence of true granulomas.

Behcet syndrome (Option C): Recurrent non-granulomatous panuveitis often with hypopyon; lacks granulomatous inflammation.

Psoriasis (Option D): May cause non-granulomatous anterior uveitis in psoriatic arthritis, without granuloma formation.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of anterior uveitis associated with arthritis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is the most common cause of anterior uveitis associated with arthritis.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic, progressive, pauciarticular(involvement of four or less than four joints) disorder involving the sacroiliac and the posterior intervertebral joints.

  • The onset is insidious with intermittent attacks of arthralgia.
  • Males in the third decade are more frequently affected than females.
  • There is a strong association with the HLA-B27 antigen.
  • Acute, recurrent iridocyclitisis part of the syndrome(25% of patients).
  • Evidence of axial skeletal involvement should be looked for in young males presenting with this ocular disorder.

Explanation of Other Options:

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option B) is typically associated with non-granulomatous systemic autoimmune arthritis; anterior uveitis is uncommon.

Syphilis (Option C) can cause uveitis but is more often posterior or panuveitis and not specifically linked to arthritis.

Tuberculosis (Option D) may lead to granulomatous uveitis but is not characteristically associated with arthritic joint disease.

questions.text: In patients with anterior uveitis, a decrease in vision due to posterior segment involvement can occur because of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cystoid macular oedema is the most common mechanism of vision loss in uveitis, as fluid accumulation in the macular cystic spaces directly impairs central visual acuity.
  • CME can occur as a complication associated with a number of ocular diseases, such as uveitis, retinitis pigmentosa, diabetic retinopathy and retinal vein occlusions.
  • CME is more likely to occur in cases of posteriorly located inflammation, and the formation of epiretinal membranes may be an associated feature.

The accumulation of fluid in CME may be secondary to dysfunctional inner or outer blood-retina barriers, for example, through increased vascular permeability. This may be mediated by:

  • Inflammatory cytokines, such as interferon-gamma, interleukin-2, and TNF-α
  • Prostaglandins
  • Vascular endothelial growth factor(VEGF) - a potent inducer of increased vascular permeability

Chronic, untreated CME may lead to permanent visual loss and is associated with damage to photoreceptors or by ischemia, as well as with retinal thinning and fibrosis.

Treatment of uveitic CME can include:

  • Topical and systemic NSAIDs
  • Corticosteroids delivered systemically, topically, regionally or intraocularly
  • Systemic carbonic anhydrase inhibitors
  • Systemic somatostatin analogues
  • VEGF inhibitors

Explanation of Other Options:

Visual floaters (Option A): Floaters arise from inflammatory cells or debris in the vitreous and cause subjective symptoms but do not substantially decrease central visual acuity.

Inflammatory disc oedema (Option B): Optic disc swelling may blur vision and cause field defect,s but is less frequent and typically spares the macula.

Exudative retinal detachment (Option C): Serous detachments can affect vision but occur less commonly than CME in anterior uveitis and often present with metamorphopsia rather than isolated central loss.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the ophthalmic outpatient department with a gradual blurring of vision in the left eye. Slit lamp examination reveals fine stellate keratic precipitates and aqueous flare, and a typical complicated posterior subcapsular cataract. No posterior synechiae were observed. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis is a chronic non-granulomatous condition presenting as low-grade unilateral anterior inflammation. It is most commonly unilateral.

Patients with FHI are often asymptomatic for many years prior to presentation, as, unlike with other anterior uveitides, they typically will have no pain, redness or photophobia.

Signs include:

  • Iris - Heterochromiaand atrophy
  • Iris rubeosis
  • Posterior synechiae are absent
  • Stellate, grey - white keratic precipitates. Located diffusely over the entire corneal endothelium.
  • Anterior chamber - faint flare and mild cellular activity
  • Russell bodies- Tiny crystals may be present on the iris surface. These are aggregations of spherical immunoglobulin.
  • Koeppe nodules can be seen - may initially lead to a misdiagnosis of granulomatous uveitis.
  • Amsler sign- Prominent iris and angle vessels that bleed after paracentesis

Complications:

  • Cataractis extremely common - a posterior subcapsular morphology is seen initially
  • Glaucomais typically a later manifestation

Treatment:

  • Long-term monitoringis indicated to detect glaucoma and other complications. The complications are treated accordingly.
  • Topical steroidsmay be used short-term for moderate to severe exacerbations, but are generally not thought to be helpful in the management of chronic low-grade inflammation.

Explanation of Other Options:

Intermediate Uveitis (Option A): Involves the vitreous and pars plana (snowbanking, floaters) rather than isolated anterior chamber inflammation with PSC cataract.

Heerfordt disease (Option B): A sarcoid variant presenting with granulomatous uveitis plus parotitis and fever, unlike the non-granulomatous Fuchs picture.

Subacute Iridocyclitis (Option D): Not a defined entity; lacks hallmark heterochromia, stellate KPs, and PSC cataract of Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis.

choices.text: Granulomatous type of low grade anterior uveitis
Topical corticosteroids are used for treatment

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Fuch's heterochromic iridocyclitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fuch's heterochromic iridocyclitis, is a chronic non-granulomatous condition presenting as low-grade unilateral anterior inflammation. It is most commonly unilateral.

Cataract (Option A) is extremely common - a posterior subcapsular morphology is seen initially

Stellate, grey - white keratic precipitates (Option B) Located diffusely over the entire corneal endothelium.

Topical steroids (Option D) may be used short-term for moderate/severe exacerbations, but are generally not thought to be helpful in the management of chronic low-grade inflammation.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with bilateral chronic uveitis. Which investigation should be ordered for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Anti-nuclear antibodies are the key screening test because ANA positivity identifies children with juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), the leading cause of chronic bilateral uveitis in this age group.

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) (formerly juvenile rheumatoid arthritis or chronic arthritis) accounts for up to 47% of all types of uveitis seen in children.

The risk factors for developing uveitis in JIA include:

  • Oligoarthritis
  • Female gender
  • ANA positivity
  • Negative Rheumatoid Factor(RF)
  • Onset of arthritis before 4 years of age
  • Presence of HLA-DRB1

While RF, HLA-B27, and inflammatory markers can aid rheumatologic workup, ANA remains the primary investigation for stratifying uveitis risk in pediatric JIA.

Explanation of Other Options:

X-ray of sacroiliac joint (Option B) is used to detect sacroiliitis in spondyloarthropathies (e.g., ankylosing spondylitis), which is uncommon in preadolescent bilateral uveitis.

HIV test (Option C): HIV can cause uveitis, but is rare in otherwise healthy children without risk factors; not first-line in chronic bilateral pediatric cases.

Mantoux test (Option D) screens for tuberculosis, a granulomatous uveitis cause, but pediatric chronic bilateral non-granulomatous uveitis is far more likely due to JIA.

questions.text: What is the most common eye manifestation of allergy to tubercular bacilli?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common eye manifestation of allergy to tubercular bacilli is chronic granulomatous uveitis. Koeppe nodules (small nodules seen at the pupillary margin of the iris) are a sign of it.

The nodules are composed of epithelioid cells and giant cells surrounded by lymphocytes.

Bussacca nodules are present at the base of the iris. more significant for granulomatous uveitis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Posterior scleritis (Option B) presents with severe pain, proptosis, and the "T-sign" on ultrasound; not an allergic granulomatous feature.

Phlyctenular conjunctivitis (Option C) is a delayed hypersensitivity conjunctival response, most often to staphylococcal proteins and less commonly to TB antigens.

Optic neuritis (Option D) is inflammation/demyelination of the optic nerve, not a typical allergic manifestation of tubercular proteins.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with blurred vision and mild eye discomfort. Slit-lamp examination reveals bilateral granulomatous anterior uveitis and multiple small yellowish iris roseolae at the pupillary margin. There is no significant vitritis. Which of the following is the most likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Yellowish nodules can develop from dilated iris vessels(roseolae) in syphilitic uveitis.

The various ocular manifestations of syphilis include:

  • Anterior uveitis - Seen in secondary syphilis. It may be granulomatous or non-granulomatous and is bilateral in 50%. Iris roseolae are seen.
  • Chorioretinitis- Often multifocal, bilateral and associated with vitritis. Exudative retinal detachment can ensue.
  • Acute syphilitic posterior placoidchorioretinopathy(ASPPC) - Characterized by large pale-yellowish subretinal lesions in the posterior pole. It is thought to be due to retinal pigment epithelial infectionand occurs more commonly in the immunocompromised.
  • Retinitis- Seen as a 'ground glass' Associated vasculitis may be occlusive and involve both arteries and veins.
  • Optic neuritis and neuroretinitis
  • Other featuresinclude conjunctivitis, episcleritis and scleritis, intermediate uveitis, glaucoma, cataract and miscellaneous neuro-ophthalmic features related to CNS involvement including Argyll Robertson pupils.

Explanation of Other Options:

Sarcoidosis (Option A) causes granulomatous uveitis with mutton-fat KPs and Busacca nodules on the mid-peripheral iris, not pupillary-margin roseolae.

Leprosy (Option C) produces larger, pale "iris pearls" or lepromatous granulomas on the iris surface, distinct from fine iris roseolae.

Tuberculosis (Option D) may show Koeppe or Busacca nodules in granulomatous uveitis, but iris roseolae are not characteristic.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with chronic ocular irritation. Slit-lamp examination reveals multiple glistening white beads (iris pearls) along the pupillary margin. Iris pearls are pathognomonic for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Iris pearls are seen as glistening white beads at the pupillary margin.
  • These lesions are composed of bacilli (dead bacteria within histiocytes).
  • These are pathognomonic for Lepromatous uveitis.
  • They are usually under 0.5 mmin diameter.

Ocular manifestation of leprosy:

  • Lids:madarosis, blepharochalasis, nodules, ectropion, entropion, lagophthalmos, reduced blinking, trichiasis
  • Cornea: thickened corneal nerves, superficial stromal keratitis, corneal anaesthesia, exposure keratopathy, interstitial keratitis
  • Iris: acute iritis(synechiae, secondary glaucoma, secondary cataract, seclusio pupillae), chronic iritis(iris pearls, iris atrophy, miosis, corectopia, polycoria, secondary cataract).
  • Ciliary body: loss of accommodation, hypotonia, phthisis.
  • Sclera: episcleritis, scleritis, nodules, staphyloma.
  • Lens:
  • Fundus: peripheral choroidal lesions, retinal vasculitis, papillitis
  • Lacrimal system: acute dacryocystitis, chronic dacryocystitis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Syphilis (Option B) causes iris roseolae, not true pearly bacillary nodules; syphilitic nodules are yellowish and vessel-based.

Sarcoidosis (Option C) produces mutton-fat keratic precipitates and Busacca nodules on the iris surface, not iris pearls.

Herpes simplex virus (Option D) is associated with granulomatous or non-granulomatous iridocyclitis, but does not produce iris pearls.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with a 2-week history of low-grade fever and bilateral parotid gland swelling. He now reports blurred vision and mild ocular discomfort. Examination reveals bilateral granulomatous anterior uveitis, facial nerve palsy, and diplopia from ocular motor nerve involvement. Which disorder best explains this presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical picture suggests Uveoparotid Fever/Heerfordt's syndrome. Sarcoidosis is the underlying disorder in Heerfordt's syndrome, linking granulomatous uveitis, parotid enlargement, and cranial neuropathies.

Uveoparotid fever or Heerfordt's disease presents with:

  • Fever
  • Parotid enlargement
  • Facial palsy
  • Ocular involvement(anterior uveitis)
  • Diplopia due to palsy of the ocular motor nerves

The entire uveal tract is involved in this disease.

The disease is self-limiting, although the iridocyclitis may cause permanent visual damage.

Explanation of Other Options:

Scleroderma (Option A) is primarily a fibrosing connective-tissue disorder; it does not feature parotitis or granulomatous uveitis.

Syphilis (Option B) can present with uveitis and cranial nerve palsies but lacks parotid enlargement and the full Heerfordt triad.

SLE (Option D) may cause various ocular inflammations (retinopathy, scleritis) but not parotid swelling or granulomatous uveitis with cranial neuropathies.

choices.text: The size of the eye decreases
Calcification may occur in Bowman's layer of the cornea

questions.text: True about phthisis bulbi
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Phthisis bulbi is an end-stage ocular disease characterised by decreased size, hypotony, and dystrophic calcification in Bowman's layer.

It can result from a variety of ocular insults, including trauma, surgery, infection, inflammation, malignancy, retinal detachment and vascular lesions.

All these lead to scarring, inflammation, atrophy and eventually disorganisation of the globe and intraocular contents.

Also called end-stage eye, phthisis bulbi can be described as a shrunken, collapsed in form, non-functional eye and presents with a small, squared-off shape, opaque and thickened cornea, thickened sclera, neovascularisation of iris, cataract, cyclitic membrane, ciliochoroidal detachment and retinal detachment.

Key Takeaways:

A mnemonic rule used to describe phthisis bulbi is '7S', referring to:

Soft - Shrunken - Shapeless - Sightless - Structureless - Squared - Sore.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs causes uveitis as a side effect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Drug-induced uveitis can occur with Cidofovir, Rifabutin, and Latanoprost.

  • Cidofovir is a nucleotide analogue antiviral and often triggers anterior uveitis via direct corneal endothelial toxicity and intraocular inflammation. Prophylactic topical steroids are recommended.
  • Rifabutin can cause a dose-dependent granulomatous anterior uveitis, typically resolving with dose reduction or cessation.
  • Prostaglandin analogues like Latanoprost disrupt the blood-aqueous barrier, occasionally leading to anterior uveitis and cystoid macular oedema.

Tubulointerstitial Nephritis and Uveitis (TINU) syndrome is a rare syndrome presenting with bilateral anterior uveitis and acute interstitial nephritis.

Drug-induced TINU syndrome has been reported following the usage of flurbiprofen and the Chinese herb 'Goreisan'.

Key Takeaways:

Always review medication history in new-onset uveitis. Cidofovir, Rifabutin, prostaglandin analogues, and TINU syndrome are key drug-related causes.

questions.text: The Tyndall phenomenon is used in the visualisation of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An aqueous flare is an optical phenomenon based on light scattering within the anterior chamber of the eye. This phenomenon occurs when an inflamed eye is viewed at right angles to a beam of light shined obliquely into the anterior chamber.

  • The fluid within the anterior chamber of the eye is called the aqueous humour. It is normally transparent and lets through all the light from the front of the eye, so it can pass through the lens to fall on the retina.
  • However, when there are proteins present inside the fluid, the light may reflect in multiple directions, leading to the scattering of light. This is called the Tyndall effectand is due to the presence of turbidity in the aqueous humour.
  • It occurs when the blood-aqueous barrier is disrupted in conditions such as anterior uveitis (e.g., HLA-B27-associated, Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis, sarcoidosis), lens-induced uveitis (phacolytic), postoperative inflammation (cataract surgery), trauma, and endophthalmitis.
  • Grading aqueous flare using standardised scales (e.g., SUN criteria) provides a semi-quantitative measure of anterior chamber inflammation, guiding treatment choice and monitoring response.

Picture showing cells and flare

Explanation of Other Options:

Keratic precipitates (Option A): Endothelial inflammatory deposits seen under direct illumination, not via light scattering in the aqueous.

Trabecular meshwork (Option B): Visualised by gonioscopy, not by the Tyndall light-scattering effect.

Posterior synechiae (Option D): Pupillary adhesions seen on slit-lamp exam with dilation, not detected by aqueous turbidity.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman with a history of chronic anterior uveitis presents for routine slit-lamp examination. What is the shape of this iris?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Iris bombe results from 360° posterior synechiae (seclusio pupillae) that trap aqueous humour in the posterior chamber, bowing the mid-peripheral iris forward into a convex, "bombe" shape.

Chronic uveitis may lead to adhesion formation.

Synechiae: adhesions develop between various structures in the eye

  • Adhesions between the cornea and iris - anterior synechiae
  • Adhesions between the iris and lens - posterior synechiae

The trapped fluid produces a characteristic funnel-shaped anterior chamber, deep centrally and markedly shallow peripherally, which promotes appositional angle closure, an acute rise in intraocular pressure, and secondary angle-closure glaucoma.

Iris Bombe and pupillary seclusion

Management includes cycloplegics, synechiolysis, and peripheral iridotomy to restore aqueous flow and prevent optic nerve damage.

Explanation of Other Options:

Concave iris configuration (Option A) is characteristic of pigment dispersion syndrome, where the mid-peripheral iris bows posteriorly.

Flat iris configuration (Option C): Normal iris contour without anterior or posterior bowing.

Plateau iris configuration (Option D): Central iris is flat, but the ciliary body plane pushes the peripheral iris forward, without true pupillary block.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with painless floaters and blurred vision in both eyes for several weeks. Slit-lamp examination reveals vitreous haze and multiple white "snowballs" in the anterior vitreous, especially inferiorly. Which condition is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Intermediate uveitis is characterised by vitritis with inflammatory aggregates (snowballs) in the anterior vitreous. Snowbanking along the pars plana may also be seen in pars planitis, the idiopathic form.

Pars Planitis is the most common form of Intermediate Uveitis, and it is bilateral in 70-80% of cases.

Patients typically report floaters and blurred vision without pain or redness, distinguishing intermediate uveitis from anterior or posterior forms.

Signs:

  1. Vitreous haze or vitritis - characteristic feature of Intermediate Uveitis
  2. Vitreous snowballs - exudates along the anterior vitreous are usually located inferiorly, but may be found throughout the vitreous cavity.

Snowbanking - Exudates along the inferior pars plana extending along the whole circumference are called as snowbanking and are pathognomonic of pars planitis.

Image of Snowballs

Explanation of Other Options:

Angle closure glaucoma (Option A) presents acutely with severe ocular pain, redness, corneal edema, and mid-dilated pupil; no vitreous snowballs.

Retinal detachment (Option B) is characterized by photopsia, progressive visual field loss, and fundus elevation on examination; does not produce snowball vitreous aggregates.

Posterior uveitis (Option C) involves chorioretinal inflammation and vitritis but lacks the classic anterior vitreous snowballs of intermediate uveitis.

questions.text: What is Macropsia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Macropsia is a visual perceptual distortion in which objects appear larger than their actual size.

Macropsia may occur in the following settings:

  • Cortical disturbances: migraine aura; strokes; temporal, parietal, or occipital lobe epilepsy
  • Retinal changes: increased photoreceptor density from macular scarring or tumors (closely spaced rods and cones make objects appear larger)
  • Accommodation errors: spasm or functional variation of the ciliary muscle leads to a "far" focus on a close object, enlarging the retinal image
  • Optical corrections & drugs: recent presbyopic lens prescriptions or certain medications can transiently induce macropsia by altering focus or retinal image size

Explanation of Other Options:

Micropsia (Option B): Objects appear smaller than normal; opposite of macropsia.

Metamorphopsia (Option C): Distorted or wavy vision of objects, not specifically size distortion.

Criss-cross lines seen (Option D) refers to entoptic phenomena (e.g., Haidinger's brush), unrelated to size perception.

choices.text: The presence of floaters is the most common complaint
Cause of painful decrease in vision

questions.text: Which of the following is true about intermediate uveitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Intermediate uveitis is characterised by vitritis with inflammatory aggregates (snowballs) in the anterior vitreous that manifest clinically as floaters. Snowbanking along the pars plana may also be seen in pars planitis, the idiopathic form.

Pars Planitis is the most common form of Intermediate Uveitis, and it is bilateral in 70-80% of cases.

Patients typically report floaters and blurred vision without pain or redness, distinguishing intermediate uveitis from anterior or posterior forms.

Explanation of Other Options:

Redness and watering (Option A) is minimal or absent because inflammation is confined to the posterior chamber.

Decreased vision (Option B): Blurred vision may occur, but is secondary to floaters, not the primary complaint.

Cause of painful decrease in vision (Option D): Intermediate uveitis is characteristically painless; pain suggests anterior involvement.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with acute anterior uveitis, marked photophobia, and an intraocular pressure of 38 mm Hg in the affected eye. Slit-lamp examination shows 2+ cells and flare without angle closure. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Topical corticosteroids are instituted first to reduce intraocular inflammation, the primary driver of trabecular meshwork obstruction and raised IOP. Timolol is added to reduce aqueous humour production, synergistically lowering IOP while inflammation resolves.

This combined approach addresses both the inflammatory and pressure-elevation mechanisms, preventing optic nerve damage and further synechiae formation.

Intraocular pressure (IOP) elevation in uveitis can be secondary to open-angle or angle-closure mechanisms. It can also be due to corticosteroid-induced glaucoma. The pathogenesis may be acute in onset, with rapid onset inflammation, obstruction of intertrabecular spaces and subsequent increased IOP.

Explanation of Other Options:

Timolol (Option A) lowers IOP but fails to control the underlying inflammation, allowing continued trabecular obstruction.

Atropine (Option B): Cycloplegia may relieve pain but can exacerbate pupillary block and angle closure in the inflamed eye.

Pilocarpine (Option D): Miotics worsen inflammation, promote posterior synechiae, and are contraindicated in uveitic eyes with raised IOP.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with a six-month history of recurrent acute anterior uveitis presents for follow-up. Which of the following is not a recognised complication of anterior uveitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Retinal detachment is not a complication of isolated anterior segment inflammation; it arises from posterior segment pathology.

Complications of Uveitis

Early (Acute) Complications

  • Inflammatory Glaucoma (Option A)
    • Trabeculitis (open-angle) from inflammatory debris obstructing outflow
    • Angle Closure from pupillary block
  • Seclusio pupillae (360° posterior synechiae)
  • Occlusio pupillae (exudative membrane over the pupil)

Late (Chronic) Complications

  • Chronic Glaucoma
    • Synechiae-mediated angle damage
    • Steroid-induced ocular hypertension
  • Lens
    • Complicated posterior subcapsular cataract (Option B)
  • Cornea
    • Band-shaped keratopathy (calcium deposition in Bowman's layer) (Option C)
  • Retina & Macula
    • Cystoid macular oedema (leading cause of vision loss in uveitis)
  • Globe Integrity
    • Hypotony (ciliary body shutdown → chronically low IOP)
    • Phthisis bulbi (end-stage atrophy: shrunken, structureless globe with calcification)
  • Optic Nerve
    • Optic neuropathy/atrophy from chronic inflammation or raised IOP

questions.text: Which one is the last to disappear in uveitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Aqueous flare reflects protein leakage from the inflamed iris and persists longest because proteins clear more slowly than cells.

Even after inflammatory cells vanish and keratic precipitates diminish, residual protein in the anterior chamber continues to scatter light, making flare detectable in healed uveitis.

The persistence of flare indicates subtle ongoing blood-aqueous barrier breakdown, guiding cautious tapering of anti-inflammatory therapy.

Explanation of Other Options:

Cells (Option A): Leukocytes clear first with effective treatment, often disappearing before any other sign.

Keratic precipitates (Option C): Endothelial deposits may linger but typically resolve or become pigmented before flare subsides.

Hypopyon (Option D): Gross layering of cells and fibrin clears rapidly with therapy, making it the earliest sign to resolve.

questions.text: The most common aetiology of uveitis is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Idiopathic uveitis accounts for roughly half of all cases.

Uveitis is defined as inflammation of the uveal tract - the iris, ciliary body and choroid. However, the retina and fluid within the anterior chamber and vitreous are often involved as well.

Anatomical Classification of Uveitis

Etiologies of Uveitis

Trauma (Option D) can precipitate uveitis via direct injury or inflammation, but comprises a small minority (<5%) of overall cases.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman came to your OPD with breathlessness, joint pain and blurred vision. Slit-lamp examination reveals bilateral granulomatous anterior uveitis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

These features are suggestive of ocular sarcoidosis.

The most common ocular manifestation overall is uveitis, reported in 30-70% of cases. Sarcoidosis can present with anterior, intermediate, posterior or panuveitis and should be on the differential for any patient with uveitis.

The most common type is bilateral anterior uveitis.

Explanation of Other Options:

HLA-B27 uveitis (Option A) typically causes acute, non-granulomatous anterior uveitis associated with spondyloarthropathies, not systemic pulmonary granulomas.

Ocular leprosy (Option B) presents with iris pearls and neuropathic signs; lacks pulmonary dyspnea and symmetric polyarthralgias.

Syphilitic uveitis (Option C) may cause granulomatous uveitis and iris roseolae, but systemic syphilis presents with rash or mucocutaneous lesions rather than breathlessness.

questions.text: Pigmented Keratic Precipitates are seen in?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pigmented keratic precipitates represent residual, melanin-laden cellular deposits on the corneal endothelium after inflammation has subsided, making them characteristic of chronic, healed anterior uveitis.

Keratic precipitates (KPs) are cellular deposits on the corneal endothelium.

  • Fine KPs are presumed to be of a non-granulomatous allergic type of inflammation
  • Large and mutton-fat KPs are associated with granulomatous inflammation.
  • Pigmented KPs reflect chronic, healed inflammation with melanin-laden cells.

Arlt's triangle

Keratic Precipitates settle down in a triangular pattern because of aqueous convection currents.

Explanation of Other Options:

Acute anterior granulomatous uveitis (Option A) features fresh, white mutton-fat KPs, not pigmented residual deposits.

Sarcoidosis (Option C) active sarcoid uveitis shows non-pigmented granulomatous KPs, pigmentation arises only in quiescent, healed stages.

Toxoplasmosis (Option D) is primarily a posterior uveitis; any anterior KPs tend to be fine and non-pigmented.

questions.text: In iridocyclitis pupil becomes
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In iridocyclitis (anterior uveitis), inflammatory mediators, particularly prostaglandins, stimulate the iris sphincter, causing miosis, while segmental posterior synechiae tether the pupillary margin to the lens capsule, producing an irregular outline.

A miotic, irregular pupil is a key clinical sign of iridocyclitis, helping differentiate it from pharmacologic or neurologic pupillary abnormalities. However, its absence does not rule out uveitis because mild miosis is difficult to detect.

Explanation of Other Options:

Round pupil (Option A): Normal pupillary shape indicates no sphincter hyperactivity or synechiae, thus not characteristic of iridocyclitis.

Mydriatic and irregular (Option C): Dilated pupils occur with sphincter paralysis or anticholinergics, not with prostaglandin-mediated miosis.

Regular dilated (Option D): A uniformly dilated pupil suggests pharmacologic or neurologic dilation, unlike the irregular constriction seen in iridocyclitis.

choices.text: Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis with systemic involvement

questions.text: Iridocyclitis is a feature of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Seronegative pauciarticular Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) accounts for 50-60% cases and carries the highest risk of chronic, often asymptomatic iridocyclitis.

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) can be defined as a group of idiopathic arthritides that occurs before the age of 16 years and persists for at least 6 weeks. It is the most common cause of uveitis in children and also a major cause of visual impairment in children.

Pauciarticular Onset

This subtype accounts for 50%-60% of all JIA and is characterised by involvement of 4 or fewer joints within the first 6 months of presentation. Occasionally, patients have no joint symptoms. Age of onset is usually less than 6 years, and it is more common among females. Joints involved are frequently the knees, ankles and fingers. The antinuclear antibody(ANA) is commonly positive and confers increased risk of ocular involvement.

Explanation of Other Options:

Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis with systemic involvement (Option A): Systemic JIA features fever, rash, and polyarthritis; uveitis is uncommon in this subtype.

Seropositive, pauciarticular JIA (Option B): Rheumatoid factor positivity is rare in pauciarticular onset and not linked with increased uveitis risk.

Seropositive, polyarticular JIA (Option D): RF-positive polyarticular JIA involves ≥5 joints and has a lower incidence of iridocyclitis compared to ANA-positive pauciarticular subtype.

questions.text: What is not true about this eye condition
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This condition is Band-shaped keratopathy. It is a calcific degeneration of the sub-epithelium, Bowman's layer, and anterior stroma, forming a horizontal opacity; it does not affect aqueous humour dynamics, so intraocular pressure remains normal.

Band keratopathy:

  • It is a corneal degeneration that is most often composed of fine dust-like calcium deposits in the sub-epithelium, Bowman's layer and the anterior stroma.
  • It is typically a band-shaped, horizontal opacity that grows from the peripheral cornea towards the central cornea.
  • Initial deposits are grey, but as the deposition progresses, the band becomes chalky-white and with dots in areas of the corneal nerve.
  • Causes: Uveitis, interstitial keratitis, superficial keratitis, phthisis, sarcoidosis, trauma, intraocular silicone oil, systemic diseases (high levels of calcium in the blood, Vitamin D intoxication, Fanconi's Syndrome, low levels of phosphorus in the blood, gout, milk-alkali syndrome, myotonic dystrophy.
  • Treatment is indicated if vision is threatened or if the eye is uncomfortable. It is important to recognise and treat any underlying condition. Improvement of vision may be obtained by scraping off the opacity. Topical disodium EDTA can be used as a chelating agent. It can also be removed with the excimer laser (phototherapeutic keratectomy). Other modalities include diamond burr and lamellar keratoplasty.

Explanation of Other Options:

Proteus syndrome (Option A): A genetic hamartomatous disorder without focal retinal necrosis or vitritis.

White dot syndrome (Option B): A group of multifocal, non-necrotising chorioretinal inflammatory conditions, not a single necrotising lesion.

Multifocal choroiditis (Option C): Characterised by multiple choroidal lesions without true necrotising granulomas or anterior uveitis.
